literal_meaning: To buy a cat in a sack.
figurative_meaning: To make a purchase without inspecting it first.
example: It's unwise to buy a cat in a sack; always check first!

literal_meaning: To tie a bear to someone.
figurative_meaning: To deceive someone with a tall tale.
example: He tied a bear to me when he said he won the lottery.

figurative_meaning: To be very clever or cunning.
example: She managed to outsmart everyone; she is clever like a fox.

literal_meaning: To grab the child by the hair.
figurative_meaning: To take advantage of an opportunity immediately.
example: When the chance arises, you should grab the child by the hair.

figurative_meaning: Stay strong and resilient in difficult times.
example: In tough times, you need to keep your ears stiff.

literal_meaning: To talk around the hot porridge.
figurative_meaning: Avoiding the main topic or issue.
example: Stop talking around the hot porridge; just tell me what you think.

literal_meaning: To throw the shotgun into the grain.
example: After all the setbacks, he wanted to throw in the towel.

figurative_meaning: That's not my problem or responsibility.
example: If you don't want to do it, that's not my beer.

idiom: Mit dem Kopf durch die Wand
literal_meaning: With the head through the wall.
figurative_meaning: To be stubborn or determined to achieve something despite obstacles.
example: He always tries to go through the wall instead of finding another way.
